title: Storms to batter Sydney and Melbourne while the rest of the nation bakes in 35C (?) temperatures
text:
A heatwave is set to sweep across parts of Ausrtalia with temperatures soaring to up to 41C, while some cities will be hit with torrential downpours.

Sydney and Melbourne will see lower than average temperatures throughout the week after being hit with heavy rain on Wednesday and Thursday with a smattering of storms amid the deluge.

But the rest of the east is set to boil as the mercury rises to 41C in some parts, with two capital cities and much of inland New South Wales and Queensland set to exceed 30C.

Rain is expected in some parts of the country, while others will experience a heatwave

The mercury will rise to 41C in some parts of the country, with two capital cities and much of inland New South Wales and Queensland set to exceed 30C

'Inland Queensland and NSW will get quite hot, peaking on Wednesday,' Weatherzone Meteorologist Hannah Wilson told Daily Mail Australia.

'Places like Blackall and Longreach in Queensland will hit 42C which is 10 degrees above average, and White Cliffs in NSW will reach 35 which is six degrees above average.

'These temperatures are heatwave conditions and they're dangerous for people in drought-effected areas, and the NSW central west where there's a high fire danger.'

Heatwave conditions in some parts of NSW and Qld will create a high fire danger

Temperatures along the east coast will stay relatively mild with Sydney and staying under 26 and Melbourne hitting a top of 23

Bureau of Meteorology State Manager Bruce Gunn told The Courier-Mail high fire risks will be a concern for the nation for the remainder of the year.

'The warmer than average temperatures and the increased chance of heatwaves, on top of the last few years of rainfall deficit, (means) it's a pretty dangerous cocktail for fire danger conditions for the rest of the year,' he said.

While temperatures along the east coast will stay relatively mild with Sydney and staying under 26 and Melbourne hitting a top of 23, places like Cairns will exceed 31 and Alice Springs will hit a roasting 39.

Rain and wind is forecast for Hobart, and South Australians are set to freeze as temperatures plummet to just 2C.
description: A heatwave is set to ravage parts of the country with temperatures soaring to 41C, while other cities will be hit with torrential downpours.
authors: Charlotte Karp For Daily Mail Australia
